content.description: One end of a string is attached to a <math alttext="0.1 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object. The string is wrapped around a pulley of known rotational inertia and radius <math alttext="0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that may rotate about its central axis. The central axis is supported by strings that are connected to the ceiling, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. In an experiment, the <math alttext="0.1 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object is released from rest, and the necessary data are collected to graph the distance fallen by the object as a function of the square of the time fallen, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A student makes the following claim.
content.question: “Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> can be used to determine the magnitude and direction of the net torque exerted on the pulley.” Which of the following statements is correct about the student’s evaluation of the data from the graph? Justify your selection.

choices.label: The student is correct, because the linear acceleration of the <math alttext="0.1 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object can be determined from the graph. The angular acceleration of the pulley can then be determined. The direction of the net torque will be in the direction of the angular acceleration.
